paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Can intratumoral mRNA vaccination sensitize tumors to immune checkpoint blockade and improve therapeutic outcomes?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: mouse efficacy
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Combination of intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti‑PD‑L1 treatment across multiple murine tumor models (L19-L20).

datasets_or_cohorts.label: mouse control
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched control groups receiving vaccine only, ICI only, or vehicle (L19-L20).

datasets_or_cohorts.label: human retrospective cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Metastatic cancer patients treated with ICIs, stratified by prior SARS‑CoV‑2 mRNA vaccination status (L21-L23).

datasets_or_cohorts.label: human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the retrospective cohort who received an mRNA vaccine before ICI (L22-L23).

datasets_or_cohorts.label: human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the retrospective cohort without prior mRNA vaccination (L22-L23).

major_limitations: Human analysis is retrospective and non‑randomized, introducing potential confounding (L48-L51).
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied among patients (L50-L51).
Mouse model findings may not translate directly to diverse human tumor types (L52-L53).
